section.sectionContent: Back pain is a common problem often caused by overusing or misusing the muscles of the back. Some causes and treatment of back pain are described in this chart.

Did your pain begin after a fall, injury, or when you lifted an object? Yes No Do you have numbness, burning, or electrical pain extending down the side of back of your leg? Yes No Are you over 60 years, have arthritis, and are you experiencing severe pain with any movement? Yes No Do you have pain when twisting, bending, or even sitting? Yes No Do you have pain that comes and goes that may have started in your teenage years? Yes No Do you have a fever? Yes No Do you have blood in your urine and one-sided back pain along with burning during urination? Yes No Is your back stiff and sore in the morning and are other joints stiff, sore, swollen, or red? Yes No Are you pregnant? Yes No Is the pain centered in the lower spine, and do you have pain down your leg? Does bending forward while walking seem to make it feel better? Yes No Do you have back pain that wakes you up at night? Have you had unintentional weight loss? Yes No Step Back Next Step

Diagnosis You may have a HERNIATED DISC . You may also have SCIATICA , caused by irritation of the sciatic nerve. Self Care See your doctor. Get plenty of rest and use an anti-inflammatory medicine, such as ibuprofen, to relieve pain. If your pain is severe, if you have lost feeling or movement in your legs, or if you have lost control of your bladder or bowels (incontinence), see your doctor or go to the emergency room right away. Start Over Diagnosis You may have a FRACTURED SPINE . Self Care EMERGENCY Call an ambulance right away. Do not try to drive to the emergency room, and try to move as little as possible. Start Over Diagnosis Your pain may be from MUSCLE SPASM (this can often feel like your back is “locked up”), a PULLED MUSCLE, or a HERNIATED DISC . Self Care Apply heat, use an anti-inflammatory medicine, such as ibuprofen, and get some rest. If you don’t get better in 2-3 days, or if your symptoms get worse, see your doctor. Start Over Diagnosis You may have SPONDYLOLISTHESIS, when one vertebra in the spine slips over another, or SPONDYLOSIS, a type of arthritis resulting from wear and tear of the spine. Self Care See your doctor. Use anti-inflammatory medicines, such as ibuprofen, to relieve pain. Start Over Diagnosis You may have a kidney infection, such as PYELONEPHRITIS . You may also have KIDNEY STONES , which can start a kidney infection, and may cause sharp, continuous abdominal or back pain. You may also notice blood in your urine and have very painful urination with or without a fever. Self Care URGENT See your doctor right away. Start Over Diagnosis You may have ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS, a form of arthritis that affects the spine. Other forms of ARTHRITIS can also cause back pain and stiffness. Self Care Use an anti-inflammatory medicine, such as ibuprofen, and apply heat to the affected area. If you do not improve, or if your pain is severe or gets worse, see your doctor. Start Over Diagnosis PREGNANCY causes stretching of the tendons (a cord of tissue connecting muscle to bone) or ligaments (tissue connecting bones to each another) around the uterus, and increases the pressure on your lower back. Self Care Apply mild heat to the back only. See your doctor if the pain continues or if fever or bleeding accompanies the pain. Start Over Diagnosis You may have a HERNIATED DISC or SPINAL STENOSIS, a narrowing of the spaces within the spine. Self Care See your doctor. Get plenty of rest and use an anti-inflammatory medicine, such as ibuprofen, to relieve pain. If your pain is severe, if you have lost feeling or movement in your legs, or if you have lost control of your bladder or bowels (incontinence), see your doctor or go to the emergency room right away. Start Over Diagnosis You may have a serious condition, including certain types of CANCER . Self Care See your doctor for evaluation. Start Over Self Care For more information, please talk to your doctor. If you think the problem is serious, call your doctor right away. Start Over Step Back Next Step
